info: Named after a Dutchman who had a market garden in the area.
Named after Desmond Adams, a subdivider who had poultry sheds and a market garden.
Mrs Rowan named it after the Christchurch racecourse, she owned a large area fronting onto Russell Road.
The road to the local airfield.
Named after an engineer with the Hutt Timber Company.
Named by Dr Bodle after an village in southeast Sussex in England.
Named after the mother of Harry Beaumont.
Named after the gemstone.
Named after the boat owned by the original landowner, it is also the name of a town in Turkey. Paul Zeusche built the boat himself, and cruised around the world.
Named after the tree.
Named after Arthur Cyril Holmes, an Anglican Minister of Religion.
Named after the tree.
Named after a famous ocean racing yacht in the 1970s.
Named after the plant.
Named after a tree, by Ransom and Ann Smyth.
Named after a tree.
Named after Manurewa's first dentist and later Mayor of Manurewa.
Named after a golf course.
Named by A. Norman, the assistant Manukau County Clerk and City secretary.
Named after Lord Beatty, who was an Admiral in the First World War.
Named after Harry Beaumont, former Mayor of Manurewa and nurseryman. He envisaged Manurewa Borough becoming part of the new Manukau City Council.
Named by Mrs Rowan.
Named after the plant.

Named after Charles Beihler, of German descent, who had a store at the end of the road. He was also a fisherman at Weymouth, and had a launch named Renahau. He built the original wharf from wattle poles, from where two barges took wattle to the tannery, and also had a grocery store by the wharf. He drowned at sea in his own boat.
Named after the Benmore Dam.
George Smith, who owned land in the area, named this road after an old Yorkshire town.
Mrs Rowan named this street after a niece's pony, it was a show pony, dappled grey and nine years old.
Named after a local farmer.
Named after an old black gate, that was between Ed and Arthur Gibbons' farm in Weymouth.
Named after Mr A. Blane, from South Africa, and a farmer in the Weymouth area.
This was part of Beaumont's nursery land.
So named as it leads to blue water.
Named by Bill Kosovich, after both Ron Wood (City Manager of Manukau City Council) and boulders.
Fred Booker was a market gardener and fisherman in the Weymouth area.
Named after Percy Bowater, a farmer who subdivided his land. He was also a Manurewa Borough Councillor and Deputy Mayor.
Named after the shearers Godfrey and Geoffrey Bowen.
Named by Mrs Rowan.
Named after Les Brett senior from Weymouth.
Named after Jack Tomlinson's wife's maiden name. Mr Tomlinson worked in plant production, and was killed in a car accident in Australia.
Named after George Brough, a stock and station agent for Dalgety's and who then had a sports shop in Papakura.
Named after Henry Brown, a local farmer. He purchased road metal for a shilling a drayload from Wiri Mountain, and wheeled it home laying the foundation for Browns Road.
Named after Russ Buller, a Manurewa Borough Councillor and railwayman.
Named by Mrs Rowan, after the variety of plum.
Named by Mrs Rowan, after the variety of plum.
Named after the tree.
Named after the tree.
The Paul farm subdivision was named after a University town in England.
Named after the famous golf course in England.
Named after a mineral rock.
Named after a wool buyer and horse trainer who owned Totara Park.
Named after Constable Ted Christmas. In 1939 he was Manurewa's first resident policeman.
Named after Sir Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister and Statesman.
Named after Mr and Mrs Joe Clark, who had a plant nursery in Clark Road. He was also a Manurewa Borough Councillor.
Named after Claude Basley, who lived on an adjoining farm.
Named after Captain Matthew T. Clayton, a sailor, farmer and artist.

named after Captain James Reddy Clendon. The New Zealand government gave him 10,000 acres of land, stretching from Papatoetoe to Papakura, and from Puhinui Road and part of Boundary Road to Brookby, and along Ranfurly and Weymouth Roads to the coast. This was in exchange for land he had in the Bay of Islands, which was taken to be the seat of government. Clendon was present at the signing of the Treaty of Waitangi as the American Consul. Clendon School was named by Barbara Dreadon.
Named after a drainage inspector with Manukau City Council.
Named after Mr A. Cole, a building inspector with Manukau City Council.
Named after Adam Collie, a sheep farmer.
Named after Tommy Corin, the first Chairman of the Town Board. He was a house builder and made the first tar-sealed road with a concrete curb in Manurewa.
Named after Charlie Costar, a builder who lived in Orams Road near Totara Park.
Named after Charlie Coxhead, farmer and drover.
Named after Kevin Crampton, who trained horses.
Named after the landowner, the land was subdivided by Universal Homes.
Named after Dalgety's woolstore. The land was a dairy farm owned by John Smyth until 1958, when he sold it to Dalgety's.
Named after a golf course in Scotland.
Named after a racehorse.
Named after David Nathan.
Named after Mr G.S. Davies, Manurewa Borough Town Clerk and Manukau City Council Properties Manager.
Named after the French version of Bloggs, who was the subdivider.
Named after Dennis Nathan.
Named after the police vessel.
Named by George Smith after Devon in England.
Named after a Manukau City Council Town Planning officer.
Named after an army man.
Named after Sir William Pickering, by Mayor Harry Beaumont. Pickering was involved in the American Space programme.

John Dreadon was a farmer who organised the Homai Railway Station to be built, and donated five hundred Pounds towards it. He also donated the land for the Station and the overhead bridge. Mr Alexander and Mr Masters also helped with the finances.
Named after Ralph Druce, a local farmer.
Named after one of the first Manukau City Councillors.
Named after the Earl and Countess of Orford, on whose land this is.
Named after Jack Eddowes, local farmer and landowner.
George McDougal subdivided this land, formerly a swamp, and named it after his wife Ellen.
Named after the tree.
Leads to Waimahia Creek and the Weymouth estuary.
Named after John Evans, who had the store at Weymouth on Beihlers Road. He also ran the bus from Weymouth to Manurewa.
Named by Ann Smyth because of the trees in this area.
Named after the tree.
Named after the plant.
Named after a local farmer.
Named after William Ferguson, a former Mayor of Manurewa Borough, who sold the Greenmeadows block to the Council. He had a dairy farm there, and raised Jersey cows.
Named after Theo Fields, an early resident.
Named after a Mr Finlay, a local farmer.
Named by Ann and Ransom Smyth in keeping with the trees and water around this area.
Named after Mr T.J. Fleming, solicitor for the Manurewa Town Board and Borough.
Named after Frances Mullions, the wife of one of the two men who jointly owned the land in this area. The other wife was Grace Keys.
Named after the flower.
Named after Frank Nathan.
Named after Charles Freshney, who owned Wattle Farm and land in Manurewa. He also planted oak trees in Alfriston Road.
Named after Max Friedlander, a German Jew and local farmer.
Named for the racing industry.
Named after the English landscape painter. The land was subdivided by Neil Housing.
Named after a famous ocean racing yacht of the 1970s.
Named after Garth Vipond, who worked for the Manukau City Council Planning Department.
Named after George Gallaher, a builder and Manurewa Town Board Chairman. Known as a "real gentleman".
Named after Nicholas Gibbons, a farmer and bushman of Weymouth.
Named after Harold W. Gibbs, a carrier and timber merchant.
Named after Mr Gladding, a painter.
Named after the golf course in Scotland, near Perth.
This was the race course road.
Named after a racehorse.
Named by George Smith, who subdivided the land, after Gloucester in England.
Named after a racehorse.
Named after the Walter's race horse, from Takanini.
Named by Mr W.T. Cox, an early resident.
Named after the semi-precious stone.
Named after the bird.
Named after Lee and Ferguson's farm, William Ferguson was the manager.
Named after the tree.
Named after a golf course.
Named after the native tree.
Renamed Halver Road, it was where the Manurewa Town Hall was situated.
Named after Admiral Halsey. The road used to have a gate at each end of it.
Formerly Hall Road, it was renamed after a general from the First World War.
Named after the Hon. Josiah Ralph Hanan, a Minister of Justice.
Named after Harrow in England.
Named after George Hazard of Weymouth.
Named after Mr Healy, who with Allan Watt and Mr White subdivided the area.
Named after the place in England.
This was the name of a school in England attended by L.D. Nathan. It was also the road leading up the hill in Manurewa.
This was the hill on the crest of the road off Hill Road.
Named after a local resident.
Named after the Australian City.
Named after a local farmer.
Harry Beaumont named this after Holmbridge in Huddersfield, England. There was a holly tree beside the bridge.
Named after Mr J. Holmes, farmer and family man.
Named after Cyril Hooks who subdivided this small farmlet. He was a Manukau City Council inspector.
Named after a golf course in England.
This was in the Beaumont subdivision, and named after the Hutt Timber Company who were the developers.
Named after Mrs Hyde, who owned land in the area.
Named after a racehorse.
Named after the place in England.
Named after the tree with berries.
Named after a Māori Reverend.
Named after the holly evergreen tree.
This is where the inlet for the creek was.
Named after a famous ocean racing yacht.
Named after the frigate.
Named after the ship.
Named after the Nathan's boat.
Named after the plant.
Named after the place in Scotland.
Named after the plant.
Named after Jack Conway, a Manukau City Councillor, long standing member of St John's and a Civil Defence leader.
Named after the Earl of Jellicoe, a former Governor of New Zealand.
Named after Dr C.C. Jenkins, who lived on the corner of Great South Road and Corin Avenue. He was Manurewa's first resident doctor.
Named after Jill, the wife of Frank Nathan.
Named after the famous Manurewa Olympian.
Named after the First World War battle at Jutland.
Named after a golf course in Hawaii.
Named after the Nathan's yacht.
Named after Mr H. Kay, Manurewa Borough Council Town Clerk.
This was on Mr C. Coxhead's farm, Maurice Dreadon put the road in.
Named after a Manukau City Council typist.
Named by George Smith, who once lived in Kent, England.
Named after the Kerr brothers who farmed and milked cows in the area, the road was originally a lane.
Named by Jim Watson, who had a local poultry farm and was a land agent. His daughter was called Kerry.
Named after a racehorse.
Named after a racehorse.
Named after Neil Kirton, a Manurewa Borough Councillor.
Renamed Kohiwi Road.
Named after Harold Knight, a Manurewa Borough Councillor.
Named after Mr Knox, who subdivided his smallholding.
Formerly Kiwi Road, kohiwi is Māori for digging a ridge.
Named by Alf Simons after the native tree. Simons was a saw doctor, farmer, developer and businessman.
Māori for quarrel over a dog.
Hugh Lambie was the first Manukau City Council Mayor, having previously been a Chairman of the Manukau County Council.
Named after Gerald Lane, a Weymouth boat builder.
Named after the plant.
Named after the plant.
Named after Lawrence Nathan. Another road in the Nathan Park subdivision.
Named after Mrs Lawson who owned this Weymouth property.
Named after the tree.
Named after a local poultry farmer, who subdivided his land.
Named after Oswald Lucas, a "jack of all trades" who was also a poultry farmer and glass house owner.
Named after Charles H. Lupton, a farmer, public benefactor, house builder, and member of the School Committee and former Chairman of the Town Board. It was later renamed Sparton Road.
Named after Percy McAnalley, proprietor of the Bellbird Inn and Manukau Borough Councillor and Deputy Mayor.
Named by Mr Beaumont.
Named after Neil McDougall who owned the Ardmore airstrip and land down the Great South Road. He was a member of the Manukau County Council.
Named after John T. McGreal, a farmer of Weymouth.
Named after John McInnes, who lived on a boat in the Manukau Harbour for many years, and was a trader in Weymouth.
Named after a local farmer. This was a Allan Watts, Healy and White subdivision.
Formerly McLaughlins Road.
William McLaughlin was a farmer living by McLaughlins Mountain. He purchased land from Edward Gibbon Wakefield and the New Zealand Land Company, and was from Scotland. Now renamed McLaughlins Lane.
Named after Alexander McLeod, a Weymouth fisherman.
Named after Mr McQuarrie, a meat inspector and racehorse owner. He had a smallholding in Mahia Road.
Named after a General Manager of Railways.
Māori for working.
Formerly Massey Road, this was named after Mr J.A. Maich, the first principal of Manurewa High School, who was also the social officer for the Manurewa R.S.A.
Named by Mrs Rowan.
Named after Mr Mail, who formed a company syndicate involved in subdivisions.
Named after the consultant acting for the subdivider.
Named after the semi-precious mineral stone.
Named after Robin Henry (nicknamed Robert) Marr, a cabinetmaker and builder. He was upset at having to pay the expenses for having Marr Road developed.
Named after the Martin brothers, who farmed and owned a lot of land in Manurewa.
Named after Prime Minister Massey, who was also the M.P. for the Manurewa area from 1911 to 1925. It was later renamed Maich Road.
Named after Gilbert Mayo, a digger of bores and wells.
Named after the tree.
So named as there were many timber mills and a flax mill here.
Named by the Hunts after friend's "Minton House" in Minton, Reading.
Named after Ces Moncrief, a Manukau City Councillor.
French for my desire.
Named after the song and place "Montego Bay" in the Carribean.
Named after a golf course in England.
Named after Cliff Morrin, a Manurewa Borough Councillor.
Mr Morris had a smallholding and a family of daughters. When he retired, he owned a Rugby car, and attended the cinema every Saturday night.
Named after Chris Mountford, a Manurewa Borough Councillor, Manukau City Councillor and Auckland Regional Authority representative.
Named after a golf course near Edinburgh in Scotland.
Named after a local resident.
Named after a Universal Homes typist.
Named after Neil Park, a Housing Corporation supervisor.
Named after the Nestle factory, which was built on the Nestle subdivision.
Named after Peter Newhook, an engineer with the Manurewa Borough Council.
Named after Percy A. Nield, who had a blacksmith shop next to the Post Office on the Great South Road in Manurewa. He did a lot of horse shoeing for the Manurewa Borough Council.
Named after the tree.
Named after a golf course in the United States.
Named after Maurice O'Connell, a Manurewa Borough Councillor and Deputy Mayor.
Named after Olive Beaumont, the wife of Harry Beaumont, and in keeping with the trees in the area.
Named after a local resident, and Ministry of Works engineer.
Named after a brand name for roofing.
Named after a Universal Homes engineer.
Named after John Palmer, he and his wife farmed this area.
Named by the Smyths, after the tree.
The road leads to a park.
Named after Patricia Davies, wife of G.S. Davies after whom Davies Avenue was named.
Named after the tree.
Named after the native tree.
Named after a local farmer, and father of Bernie Ross.
Named after a golf course in the United States.
Named after a horse trainer in Takanini.
Formerly Morris Road.
Named after the tree.
Named after a golf course near Ayr in Scotland.
Named by Mrs Rowan.
Named after the tree.
Named after the English railway station.
Named after Lord Ranfurly.
Māori for army of people.
Named after an old Auckland yacht.
Māori for sky fathers.
Named after the owner of a grocery shop opposite the Manurewa Post office in Station Road. He owned land, and his wife, Ann, named a lot of streets in Manurewa.
Maori for yonder black pigment.
Named after the plant.
Named after Rebecca Hazard, who was one of the Gibbons family from Weymouth.
The road that led to St John's redoubt.
Named after a famous racehorse.
Named after the native tree.
Māori for twisted cord.

Named by Gordon McCallum after George Rogers, who had a shoe shop and was the first person to build a house in this street. In 1939 he was a taxi driver and a member of the Manurewa Fire Brigade. He was also a Manurewa Borough Councillor.
Named by Mrs Rowan. Romney sheep were farmed in this once rural area.
Named after Ron Oak, a subdivider and builder.
Named after the children of the developed, Ron, Doreen and Lynette.
Named after Ron Wood, former City Manager of Manukau City Council.
Named after the Irish Earl of Roscommon.
Named after the tree.
Named after contractors Wilson and Rothery.
Mr Rowan and wife Anita farmed in this area.
Named after Percy Roy, a farmer from Weymouth, who used a house here as his summer residence. He used a horse and cart for transport.
Named after Ruby Eddowes.
Edward Russell, solicitor, owned land in this area, and Mr Fawcett tar sealed the road in earlier days.
Named by Mr Lomas after Ruth Parkinson, the previous landowner. The land was obtained under the Public Works Act.
Named after John Ryan, the subdivider.
The Scotts lived in Alfriston, and both died of the flu within 24 hours of each other.
Named by the subdivider, as it looked seaward.
Named by Mercantile Developments after a racehorse.
Named after Bishop Selwyn, as it led to the Anglican Church on Weymouth Road.

Named after Arthur Clifton Axford Sexton, a lawyer with a wooden leg. He was an Independent Country Party (pro Social Credit) M.P. for the area from 1935 to 1938, and lived south of the first bend in Hill Road. Every day as soon as he saw the train coming he walked from home, getting there just in time.
Named after Braden Sharkey, Manukau City Councillor and former County Treasurer.
Named after Sharland's, which had a large pharmaceutical factory in the area.
Named after the racehorse Shifnal Chief.
This was in the McDougal block.
Named after a Malaysian town known to the developer.
Named after a famous ocean racing yacht of the 1970s.
Named after a Universal Homes surveyor.
Named after a famous ocean racing yacht of the 1970s.
So named as it faces south.
Formerly Lupton Road, it was named after a racehorse.
Named after a golf course in southern England.
Named after Major St John, who commanded the First Waikato Militia, and later became a Lieutenant Colonel. It was erected for protection against Māori attackers.
The road leading to the Manurewa Railway Station.
Named after Sterling Pharmaceuticals.
Named after a British Admiral, and located on the Kitchener estate.
Named by Mrs Rowan after their property, originally named by Edward Russell.
Named after a golf course in England.
Named by Charlie Beecroft after Sue his daughter, and Wyn his granddaughter.
Named by Bill Smart.
Named after Ernest Sykes, farmer and builder.
Named after a town in Malaysia known to Mr Tomlinson the developer.
Named by Alf Sims, landowner, developer, saw doctor and businessman.
Formerly Goodwin Way, but changed due to new owners of the land.
Named after a Manukau City Council engineer.
Latin for tulip tree.
Named after a golf course in England.
Māori for long road.
Named after Jack Tomlinson, who was killed in a car accident in Australia. He owned a flower nursery and his wife was a Miss Brouder.
Named after a precious rock.
Named by Enos S. Pegler.
Named after the native tree.
Named after a semi precious rock.
Named after the Army camp.
Named after Dr Hoskin, who was killed in Canada during the Second World War during a training flight with the airforce. His parents owned the surrounding land.
Named after the native bird.
Named after a racehorse. Mr Streven subdivided the land, which was originally the Watkins farm and which ran pedigree Jersey cows.
Named after Una Ross, from Ross Roofing.
Named after a horse trainer.
It means view.
Named after a famous ocean racing yacht of the 1970's.
Māori for leading to the water.
Māori for water action towards speaker.
Māori for water for him or her.
Māori for water road.
Named after a waterfall in Totara Park.

Named after Sir Horace and Lady Walpole, who owned the land before subdivision. The Earl came to New Zealand for health reasons, and was a descendant of Sir Robert Walpole, Prime Minister of England in 1721 and created Earl of Orford in 1722.
Named after a farmer, and Queen Street, Auckland shoe merchant. He served on both the Manukau and Auckland City Councils.
Named after a local family.
Named after a local farmer.
Named after the wattle trees planted there, the area was subdivided by Roy Munnings.
Named after Allan Watts an engineer who surveyed this area, with Mr Healy and Mr White.
Named after Weymouth in England.
Named after Mr White, who with Mr Healy and Allan Watts, were the engineers who surveyed this area.
Named after William Eddowes.
Now known as the Wiri district. Woodside was the original centre of settlement.
Named after the English poet.
Named after a Universal Homes surveyor.
Named after a semi precious mineral.
